acquainted with the idea of unschooling, and they are very different indeed 
(mostly depends on the state's technical definition). I applaud Logan for 
presenting his information, but it is no different than children exposed to 
perform in large audiences in general. Kids are getting better exposure 
these days, and adults are finally giving children more respect.
comments.author: Lauren Spradlin

comments.text:
I think it's as simple as this: If you want to try and gather more details 
on home schooling vs what you perceive as "hackschooling children" go to 
Unschoolery.com and there's a good site to share in a good manner and hash 
it out. As for Logan LaPlante I really am just inspired that this little 
guy got up there and did this and I think he is authentic and pretty 
courageous for doing it. I've not seen any talks by a 13yo that were this 
good. There's one by someone who's 15 and that's a big difference. Amazing

comments.author: loopBum

comments.text:
+loopBum I don't find this "hackschooling" equivocal to home schooling. For 
my children, unless they express otherwise, they will be home schooled. 
They can be whatever they want when they grow up, but they will be having a 
heavy emphasis placed on math, science, and programming if I can convince 
them. This isn't to say play time isn't important; it is. However, the 
methods of play time vary per family, and clearly these parents saw the 
outdoors as the play outlet. I think you're right, in that the parents were 
very cognizant of Logan's needs. This is 1 case. My only point was that if 
we are to truly see this as an alternative educational lifestyle, then I'd 
like to know how many of these hackschooling children express interest in 
STEM fields. Compare that to a statistic for traditional schooling, and I'd 
like to see the difference.
comments.author: Lauren Spradlin

comments.text:
+kittycolourful +Lauren Spradlin ...a lot going on now regarding Univ. Core

saw potential at home & something caused a situation where they had to make 
the best choice for their child.
comments.author: loopBum

comments.text:
+Lauren Spradlin Yeah absolutely. Couldn't agree more. I think if this 
system is to be the standard, higher level institutions need to be one of 
the first, if not the leaders to initiate change. Hidden curriculum skills 
required by universities (i.e the ability to take a test; monitor your own 
learning etc) are still a (evil?) necessity. There needs to be a standard 
to which learners are held, especially if others depend on the accuracy and 
skill level of that student. 
Also, I have not looked too far into this program. Do you know if it is 
accredited? What does the student achieve at the end of the curriculum?
comments.author: NaturallyKaty

comments.text:
+kittycolourful Agreed, but you have to be careful using the traditional 
school argument. These hackschool/unschool/whatever-you-want-to-call-it 
extreme supporters will probably say that this is the fundamental flaw in 
traditional teaching; that traditional school only works because our 
current society is used to functioning on top of it, and that if given a 
chance, hackschooling could prove to be a viable alternative. There's also 
the prodigy problem, where you do have those rare few who are learning STEM 
related material on their own (e.g. Terence Tao). I can see extreme 
hackschool supporters claiming he might have been the same genius had he 
been left to his own devices and brought up under their view of education. 
Imo, "hackschooling" is only a viable option for kids who are not pursuing 
serious STEM fields.
comments.author: Lauren Spradlin

comments.text:
Not to mention that the traditional route of schooling not only affords a 
student the skill set and curriculum necessary for their chosen field of 
work, but standards ensure that if he wants to attend any high level 
institution for STEM fields, he needs to have the necessary credentials. 
That's one of the few downsides to schooling outside of traditional means.
comments.author: NaturallyKaty

l'homme, son vrai bien ; elle le marque, comme l'image de l'empereur marque 
la pièce d'argent. C'est pourquoi le Seigneur ajoute : « Rendez à César ce 
qui est à César. » Comme s'il disait : De même que vous rendez à César son 
image, ainsi rendez à Dieu votre âme, ornée et marquée de la lumière de sa 
face.

Saint Antoine de Padoue (v. 1195-1231), franciscain, docteur de l'Église 
Sermons pour le dimanche et les fêtes des saints (trad. Bayart, Eds. 
franciscaines 1944, p. 249)

ne peut pas dire que ce soit ton cas quant à tes détracteurs.
Chose que Danda à surement remarqué. Tu ramènes ton âge avancé de 50 ans 
comme une validation de tes dires et de ton expérience... tu sais que j'ai 
visité plus de 40 pays -- alors que j'ai 25 ans? Que j'ai vécu plus de 3 
mois dans la rue? Je doute qu'avec tes 50 ans tu aies ne serait-ce qu'une 
portion de mon expérience de vie; surtout en ce qui concerne les drogues... 
on voit clairement que tes notions sont en surface uniquement.
Maintenant... je ne veux pas argumenter ni discuter parce que tu es le 
genre de personne qui n'est pas capable de discuter autrement qu'en 
essayant d'imposer ton point de vue douteux que tu essayes pourtant de 
faire passer pour une vérité universelle. En plus du fait que tu estimes 
que d'autres se font juge... alors que tu te permets de juger de bien 
nombreuses personnes dans tes précédents commentaires.
Mon beau-père est Gilles Langloys -- le seul Chaman reconnu de France et 
l'auteur de la Guérison de l'habitat. J'ai beaucoup écouté ce qu'il avait à 
dire et j'ai appris de ses enseignements. Je me suis ouvert à beaucoup de 
choses autour de moi -- mais rien de ce que tu prétends être ce qui est.
Tu penses être sur un plan spirituel supérieur au sien? Tu te crois 
supérieure? Prétention, présomption, mensonge sont des mots qui te siéent à 
merveille d'après tes commentaires précédents. Tu es pleine de vent et de 
haine lorsque l'on te met en doute.
Tu n'es ouverte et instruite en rien -- sauf de manière prétendue. Je peux 
prouver de manière simple qu'il est mon beau-père (et contrairement à tes 
prétendus documentaires sur la drogue tu peux trouver ses ouvrages sur 
internet).
Quand tu auras 51 ans j'espère que ton hypocrisie & ta mythomanie auront 
disparues.
Contrairement à toi... c'est mon dernier commentaire et je ne suis 
intervenu de nouveau que parce que tu crachais un venin haineux sur deux 
autres personnes.
Je tire ma révérence.

top_comment.text:
As usual, this is another TED (x) talk that sounds great and makes people 
feel good, but is ultimately naive and pointless.

I mean, people realize that these types of "creative" home schooling is 
only possible because so few kids do it right? The public education system 
is responsible for educating and evaluating hundreds of thousands of 
students, if not more. Inevitably, this requires a systemic structure and 
mechanical teaching techniques. It is unfeasible to accommodate for the 
creativity and subjectivity of a large number of people.

Sure, elementary schools could be more creative, but beyond that it is 
utterly stupid. Like the examples that he gave, could you imagine bringing 
a whole class of high school students on a field trip just to learn about 
newton's laws? And also doing something "creative" and "fun" for everything 
they're supposed to learn? They would learn less in a whole school year 
than what we are currently learning in a month.

Not to mention the extremely subjective and unreliable marks that these 
home schools produce. This kid will be having fun building stuff to "learn" 
while other traditional school students actually read a textbook and do the 
work. How are universities supposed to pick applicants if everyone's 
submissions resulted from a unique, unregulated, non-standardized, 
pick-your-own-adventure education? They can't.

That's why things are the way they are now. They're reliable, standardized, 
efficient, and are able to accommodate the mass numbers of students that 
need an education. These "creative" homeschooling or alternative schooling 
programs only work because they exist in small numbers. So again, like most 
of these videos: great food for thought, but not practically useful.﻿
top_comment.author: Jeremy Li

comments.text:
It's actually the opposite. My children learn more in one summer of school 
in the forest, on any subjects: astronomy, physics, medicine and 
literature, than school year. Kids were relaxed, and attending classes at 
suitable to them time( there were several lectures during the day) and were 
free to leave and come as they were more interested in one subject, or 
another. In just one summer they learn a year's programme at home too. I 
was also self- educated. Point is: school can't make you smart, If you are: 
you need your space to think, and concentrate; and you will learn. If you 
are not a good learner, school will only emboss some basic knowledge into 
your memory, but won't make you intelligent. In the end, while sitting at 
those desks, kids will not learn how to be smart, but also miss the 
opportunity to practice things they might well be good at (be that a 
sportsman, or  a seller). There is talent for something in everyone, and 
school makes everyone follow one pattern, not all; depriving children of 
opportunity to develop their own. I love university, since we choose for it 
ourselves, and follow our natural interests there, and are free to leave 
once it does not give us knowledge we seek; but school- it's imprisonment 
of mind and talents. Mostly a place of competitiveness and bullying, and 
following trends. HIghly intelligent children don't like classical school 
system, and often rebel. Wasting energy on fighting to have some time for 
themselves, fighing social standarts; instead of using all the time for 
their creativity and talents- that's school.
comments.author: Leyla Azeri

comments.text:
+Jeremy Li I would just like to say that while the system is "efficient" at 
getting students diplomas, many don't retain the knowledge they are tested 
on. I just graduated, and I, and my friends, would study for a test and 
then forget most of the information we were supposed to learn. How is that 
truly efficient learning? I don't think what Logan talked about would be 
practical for the amount of students in public school, but something needs 
to change.
comments.author: Kim Hearn

comments.text:
+meghan rudisill SATs are not the only thing universities look at, and I'm 
also in Canada. Yes textbooks, curriculums, teachers, etc. vary across the 
country, but they're still GENERALLY similar and reliable (might be worse 
for the US, idk). Homeschooling can be compliant with public school 
curriculums, but its too hard to actually regulate each individual home 
school and ensure proper procedures. Yes, there are problems with many 
public school systems, and yes, there are probably many great home schools, 
but overall I would still have more faith in the marks of someone who went 
through a public school system than someone who was schooled in their own 
home by their parents.

And in regards to the "are they trying to make it fun for anyone?" point. I 
don't care whether or not they're trying to make it fun. I'm just saying 
that the traditional teaching method of teaching from a textbook in the 
classroom is fast and efficient. If they're going to change the teaching 
method to something that is "creative", such as going on field trips or 
doing experiments, each topic would take a long time and students wouldn't 
learn nearly as much as they are now every school year.
comments.author: Jeremy Li

comments.text:
+Jeremy Li I have to respectfully disagree with some of your points. You 
did say that elementary schools could be more creative and I agree. My mom 
was an elementary school teacher who was incredibly creative in her 
methods. She was able to do this by accommodating for the creativity of her 
whole class through a variety of methods, but one was centers. Centers 
evolved from Howard Gardner's Theory of Multiple Intelligences. This theory 
also gives validity to your comment that making everything then learn fun 
impractical. Obviously what is fun for one person might be tedious to the 
next, but I think one of his points is are they trying to make it fun for 
anyone? To address the comment about unreliable marks of home schoolers I'd 
like to point out most college bound home schoolers still take the SATs. 
That is a big part of how students are admitted still. I am very interested 
to know why you think the education system is standardized? Academically 
standards, textbooks, curriculums, and lesson plans vary not just from 
state to state but from teacher to teacher. In the last decade there have 
been schools here in Arizona where the students were instructed in their 
first language of Spanish with English comprehension being so low the 
teachers had to translate the questions on the state tests. Their are 
school with little to no budgets where the majority of the class is 
struggling to work at grade level while schools in wealthier districts are 
able to take advantage of tax credit money and have rock walls in pe, 
gardens on campus, and iPads for every student. The whole reason common 
core is becoming so popular is it is an attempt to create standardization 
where there hasn't been. Maybe schools are more standardized in your area, 
but in AZ I'm sad to say we are struggling. This young man's ideas are not 
all completely impractical. I hope the people in charge continue to seek 
how to grow and better our education system.
comments.author: meghan rudisill

comments.author: TreborHG_93

comments.text:
That is the most common assumption by those who have not researched 
homeschooling. You will be surprise that that is not the case.

http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/dec/13/home-schooling-socialization-not-problem/

"When measured against the average Canadians ages 15 to 34 years old, 
home-educated Canadian adults ages 15 to 34 were more socially engaged (69 
percent participated in organized activities at least once per week, 
compared with 48 percent of the comparable population). Average income for 
home-schoolers also was higher, but perhaps more significantly, while 11 
percent of Canadians ages 15 to 34 rely on welfare, there were no cases of 
government support as the primary source of income for home-schoolers. 
Home-schoolers also were happier; 67.3 percent described themselves as very 
happy, compared with 43.8 percent of the comparable population. Almost all 
of the home-schoolers — 96 percent — thought home-schooling had prepared 
them well for life."

top_comment.author: Samuel Cright

comments.text:
+Samuel Cright But there is no "you" without the environment, because you 
cannot realise (from the point of bringing to reality) that only you is 
you, and you are not others, but yourself, in comparison with other human 
beings, other species, nature, the universe. From that basic premise of 
consciousness, you cannot separate the environment from the "you". That 
type of awareness is the one that puts you in a social context, 
automatically. It's like saying that the Earth only relies on itself to 
continue existing, without having to rely in the laws of the universe.  

I agree with you with the visibility of the space-time paradigm example, 
and of course it is intangible, it's just a consensus of what we think that 
that "time" or "cronology" represents. Maybe we have to rethink the way 
this kind of thought is applied to existence.
comments.author: Parmid Oproxydim

comments.text:
+Parmid Oproxydim The past and future are too intangible to believe they 
are part of us. We do not know them and they do not know us. The present is 
the only defining moment.

My point isn't about making a difference, if you want to go ahead and try. 
It's about how you would even know if you made a difference. You call it 
existentialism but I am not at all arguing the existence of the everything. 
I'm talking about finding purpose in yourself regardless of your 
environment. Appreciating existence for existing.
comments.author: Samuel Cright

comments.text:
+Samuel Cright I agree with your point. You cannot expect to make a 
difference in the present while trying to live in the past or in the 
future, in a nostalgic or hopeful way. You have to be down to earth and 
realistic about it, because if you don't, you are not taking into account 
what is happening in the immediate instance of time, which are the 
continuous amounts of time. But at the same time, I think there's a part of 
us that doesn't want to make the mistakes of the past, and want to strive 
to a better version of the future. You cannot loose sight of the 
period/moment you are experiencing right now, and if you do so, you will be 
out of your own time. 

And at the same time, think about our family/traditions/education/cultural 
paradigms. Aren't we being grown with a "methodology" of life based in the 
past, suposedly useful for the future? I think we are constantly "present" 
in all the time periods at once. I don't wish to enter to the realms of 
existencialism right now, but our conscious awareness make us go further of 
what is only flesh and bone, and therefore, meaning and explanation of 
everything.  

Anyways, it's important to take into account what you've just said about 
what approach of "time" we use in order to create our current reality.
comments.author: Parmid Oproxydim

comments.text:
+Parmid Oproxydim You kind of get it but I am talking about finding your 
own way just from a more ancient perspective. The problem is when people 
focus on the past/future and lose sight of the present. Life is the moment 
you are experiencing right now. It is not our improvements or adjustments 
or our perception of happiness.

comments.author: Marvin Evolution

comments.text:
+Adrien Perié I don't really mean to be intrusive, but where exactly did 
you get your 'fun fact' that "90% of the people on YouTube argue for the 
sake of arguing?" I sincerely doubt that you have that information. Also, 
there are many different types of intelligence. IQ, of course, is one of 
the main ones. There is also intelligence in the patterns of your thoughts 
(which are technically created by the combination of your brain chemistry 
and environment/experiences) and intelligence in understanding others. The 
latter is known as EQ, or Emotional Intelligence Quotient. Having a high IQ 
is only one piece of the puzzle for mastery of self, and doesn't 
automatically mean you can out-think anyone. It simply means that your 
brain operates in a way that is higher than average for the specific things 
that an IQ test measures. (Also, IQ tests are NOT the most accurate of 
exams, and different tests can have different results.) That being said, I 
mostly agree with your original comment here. I believe that if this kid 
really knew and understood what he was talking about, he would have 
elaborated more on specific details and what was wrong with our current 
form of education. I don't mean to brag, but I believe that if I were to 
talk about something I really understood, I would be able to give a much 
more fluent and informative speech specifically stating the problems and 
changes necessary with overwhelming evidence to back myself up. Have to 
cover all of your bases, right? I'm not really aware of the way to properly 
end a comment, and the usual "Good day sir" endings are annoying and 
pathetic, so I'll just sign off.

So +Adrien Perié...Congratulations. You've bolstered your position with 
trivial IQ statistics, a proclaimed "deep insight" of your human kin, and 
use of some flowery language. Okay...

1. Intelligence should never need to be proven. If you actually posses the 
superior intelligence you've so righteously told us about-then you need 
simply to exude it-not pester us with endless references to it. For this 
you have degraded your own social image. Tisk tisk.

Now. Onto what actually matters: What have you gained from your comments? 
Did your effort in crafting fancy Youtube comments benefit your knowledge 
of human interactions? Do you have a different or reinforced perspective of 
this 13 year old's experience because of it? Going back to the root of your 
gripes: You speak about this kids intentions--that he's talking only to 
impress upon the adults the success of "hackschooling" yet he maintains 
only superficial understanding of its happiness.

EDIT: The upcoming "Well What of it" comment is directed towards your 
statement to ThePiscesmMended: "you might have realized all I meant was 
that my """expert""" opinion of someone who knows how to listen to others 
and has had the experience of being a high potential kid was that this kid

audience.

-Austin

comments.text:
+ThePiscesmMended
The kind of verbal abuse I spout ? And then you tell me that "got pulled 
out of public school because you were a/the problem for those around you, 
and it was safer to isolate you than have you in a public setting."
What kind of person would make assumptions like that ? How is it not verbal 
abuse ?
Since you insulted me let me demonstrate to you how wrong you are about me 
and my experience. Every single thing you said is litterally the opposite 
of the truth.
I had to fight really hard to get the homeschooling I needed. I was pushed 
again and again in what amounted for me to torture, back in a class 
surrounded by people with whom I shared next to nothing until I was 15 when 
those around me finally grew up enough so that I could at least enjoy some 
communication with them. I started doing everything I could to miss classes 
without hurting my good mother too much, and ultimately started taking 
pankillers eveyday to stand going in internship at a school 300 miles from 
my home where I only got to see my first serious girlfriend once a week. 
After even that failed I finally got my shot at homeschooling and blew it 
because I had become seriously addicted which helped me fuel an attitude of 
complete refusal of accepting my responsibilities since those used to be 
standing being mentally tortured every day.
I wasn't the guy bullying you. I was the guy being targetted because I 
didn't give a shit about what my classmates cared so much about and 
thankfully being able to defend myself and make a few friends I can't 
complain about having been seriously abused like so many others are.
Now I'm 19 years old, trying to break out of my addiction, finding a job 
while doing my homeschooling to get my diploma (In France Scientific 
Baccalauréat) so that I can join a school next year (university...) 
thankfully with only two years of time lost instead of 3 or 4 years for 
others I know of.
If you had red my comment carefully instead of following your primary 
instincts of bullying victim (and then you talk to me about my experience 
negatively affecting MY views !)
you might have realized all I meant was that my """expert""" opinion of 
someone who knows how to listen to others and has had the experience of 
being a high potential kid was that this kid was performing a show to 
please adults, not because he was dumb but because he was smart. That's it.

top_comment.text:
In life, you learn that sometimes you have to do the right thing, which 
doesn't always make you happy. You cannot teach happiness in school, but 
you can teach a kid how to rationalize a problem, how to interact with 
other people.

Going to school has never made me unhappy (except for Mondays) and has 
never prohibited me from being creative. In some classes I was encouraged 
to be creative, while in others I was thought fixed sciences that leave 
little room for creativity.

Most kids that are home-schooled in the USA are home-schooled because their 
parents don't want them to learn about the Big Bang and Evolution. This 
affects kids more, in terms of self-development than public-schooling.

Public schooling should be reformed and we have the tools and technology to 
do it. But, creativity will not help you in every situation and happiness 
is something you find out on your own.﻿
top_comment.author: Alexandru Avram-Rusu

comments.text:
I truly agree with this part "Public schooling should be reformed and we 
have the tools and technology to do it.". Hopefully someone can collaborate 
both homeschooling and public-schooling with little enhancement to become a 
better education system which can teach better for public, in any nation, 
races and basically whoever.
comments.author: haryanto wang

comments.text:
+FreeThinkingMama 
That is the main problem with homeschooling. We had a case in Romania of 
parents not wanting to give their kids to school because they would learn 
about Evolution and they would come into contact with people of other 
religions. Eventually, there is no homeschooling here, so they were forced 
to let their kids go to school.

In the end, a parent could be able to teach his children, but maybe he/she 
should pass some exams, have training sessions, participate in homeschool 
groups and should receive assistance and guidance. Also, the child should 
be evaluated at least once per semester so that the state can ensure that 
he/she is though well.

I get that a lot of people are not satisfied with the public schooling 
system. My mother has been working as a teacher for the past 30 years and 
she is not satisfied either, especially since in the last couple of years 
she has to spend some of her free time to write reports about nothing, 
instead of, for example, planing school trips.
comments.author: Alexandru Avram-Rusu

comments.text:
+Alexandru Avram-Rusu It seems like you grew up with great parents who 
cared a lot about you and your education. I agree with you about the 
majority of homeschoolers just keeping kids out for the sake of religious 
reasons. We had to leave a homeschool group once because of the gay 
bashing. (I am not gay, but my niece is. It felt kind of insulting to me to 
have to stand and listen to a group of parents...well you know how people 
can be.) I have met some in our group that are sweet parents, but they seem 
to take their children's education for granted. For instance when I asked 
this one lady we met up with at the park, "So have your kids finished all 
their work for today?" She replied, "Well no, we mostly just did chores and 
they read a little bit from their weekly reader. We may or may not get to 
it today." My question is how many days does that happen? If it's all the 
time then they are better off in school. Some I know just do reading and 
math then use the Bible for science and history. Then of course their are a 
lot that go by a program that keeps them at home all the time and they 
haven't got much of a social life. My philosophy is you just have to find 
the right balance. If you want to teach your children about religion 
then they need to understand that there are many religions out there. If 
they thought everybody believed the same thing when they moved out on their 
own...that would end in culture shock.
comments.author: FreeThinkingMama

comments.text:
+FreeThinkingMama You have smart kids, I will give you that.

Hell, I could have been home schooled My mother is one of the best teachers 
in the town I live and and I am currently working in accounting with my 
father, so I could have avoided public schooling. 

Plus, public schooling does not impose you not to work extra time with your 
kid at home, if you are willing. I had English private tutoring, French 
private tutoring, Math private tutoring, History private tutoring (went to 
History Olympics), Piano lessons, Karate lessons, Computer Programming 
lessons.

I liked public schooling, with it's ups and downs and I think it should be 
reformed because it has not kept up with social and technological 
advancements.

I don't think everyone has the ability to teach children, nor the time. 
Maybe you do. But the problem remains that a lot are home schooled just so 
they don't learn about Evolution and The Big Bang because they contradict 
religious views.

I hope you look beyond your personal convictions when you are teaching your 
kids.
comments.author: Alexandru Avram-Rusu

comments.text:
+Alexandru Avram-Rusu If it were just once then probably, but twice...? If 
your not a native English speaker than I hope if you live in America that 
you moved from a foreign country, and in the event that you have then you 
would probably not understand just how bad of an education some kids would 
be getting by going to their local public school. I have seen it myself. My 
kids as previously stated are homeschooled because they get a better 
education here. When my son was in his kindergarten year of homeschool, he 
helped his first grade cousin who was in public school learn how to read. 
She recently got put in the K12 program at home. She should be in the 6th 
grade, but could not do the math. They bumped her back to 5th and my son 
has been helping her catch up. I'm glad he can. It is a great challenge 
teaching three different grade levels at once! I would not send my kids to 
that school system though. One child learns from another sometimes and it 
is at a higher grade level. For instance my 1st grader has learned 
multiplication and division simply by sitting at the table with the older 
two. Another thing people do not know about homeschoolers is they do have 
meet ups with other homeschoolers. Our kids get to do things that some 
schools don't get to. Last year we visited the Air Force base, fire 
station, police station, had picnics and play dates at the park with other 
homeschoolers a.k.a. friends!  We went to a neat little farm, the youngest 
had a fancy little Kindergarten graduation etc. At the end of the year 
after taking the state tests the oldest passed on grade level. Only the 
oldest because the younger two do not take the test till the end of their 
third grade year, and I know when they do they will do great.

+Alexandru Avram-Rusu "What's the point in observing my classmates' plants

Wow, either you had really crappy teachers, if they would fail you because 
your experiment didn't go right, or you have actually never done an 
experiment. I'm not sure which one would be worse. 
You aren't graded on your ability to grow plants, that would be absurd. You

you record the data. Finally, you write your conclusion. 
Have you really never done a lab write up? I find that horrifying, and it 
only makes my view of public school more negative. 

"If I wanted to do biology experiments, I would have enrolled in a biology 
college or biology specialization class in high-school. " 
So you will read all about the principles of evolution, but you don't want 
to do any of the work associated with practical experience? 

"I like science, but that doesn't mean I have to practice it..."
Then what you're doing isn't "science" it is analysis. You're just 
memorizing the results of someone else's experiments. How can you succeed 
in a science field if you are unwilling or incapable of doing your own 
experiments?

Basically, what I got from this is that in your science education, you have 
never gotten any practical experience, and if you did you were graded on 
the results of the experiment, not a well-thought-out lab paper, which it 
appears you've never written. That's just SAD. But hey, at least you know 
the principles of evolution!

comments.author: Linda Merson

comments.text:
+Alysia Robertson 

Which part of this infographic says the success level is not contingent on 
income or education level of parents? (Hint: no part of this infographic 
states or supports that claim.) In fact, there is one part of the 
infographic which DOES show education level of parents, and shows that 90%+ 
of homeschooling parents have at least some college.  Guess what?  This is 
a greater level of education than parents of public-school parents, so that 
right there completely rejects your claim (you think 29% of public school 
parents have a Masters or Doctorate degree like the guy in this picture???)

This infographic is 100% unscientific data manipulation, and here's why: 
 Socio-economic-status HAS, in fact, been proven to be a huge factor in 
educational performance.  What the homeschooling stats here don't show is 
that the vast majority of students in many public schools are low-SES, 
while the majority of homeschooled children are higher-SES.  So saying 
things like "homeschoolers score in the 87th percentile" is completely not 
scientifically valid -- because you aren't isolating the variable (the 
confounding variable here is SES, among others: single vs. dual-parent 
home, for example.)

The only way to have ANY validity to these claims would be to compare 
homeschoolers to public schoolers of the same background (not very easy to 
do, due to the variety of factors, but finding scores of those with the 
same mean or median income levels, or income-relative-to-state-average, for 
example, would be a start.)

Oh, and then there's the outright fallacious claim that the average 
homeschool family spends only $500 per year.  Nope, false -- because there 
is an opportunity cost that is being spent when a parent stays home instead 
of having a job. If that parent even worked just a minimum wage job, they 
would be earning at least $15,000 per year.  Therefore, homeschooling is 
costing the family at LEAST $15,000/year -- or >50% more than the per-pupil 
cost of public schools.

My homeschooled cousin is from a two-parent, reasonably-high SES... and 
after "graduating", he went on to work as a retail clerk at GameStop. 
Should I put THAT on an infographic?

comments.text:
I somewhat agree +Matthew Donnelly.

Instead of a class I believe that personal development should just be apart 
of everyday life for everyone. 

Having a class would expose people to the benefits of living a life full of 
happiness, respect, and love but just like most things that become 
systematized and generalized, the passion for the subject is diluted and 
only a few really take it to heart.

I was exposed to +Tony Robbins when I was 10.  And you're right, his words 
sound like my subconscious. 

Having more people like us sharing our passion for a life full of 
happiness, respect, and love is what is going to change the world.  Our 
passions are not diluted to due governmental control.  People follow us 
because they see themselves in us and are inspired to be more than what 
they are now. 

I believe the world will change when people start looking for solutions and 
start finding like minded people; people they can learn and grow with. 

Self esteem and self confidence are the cornerstones of happiness and in 
order for kids to have those qualities, parents and teachers need to have 
those qualities too.

top_comment.text:
Happiness and creativity should be learned, just like math.

How inspiring it is to watch Logan LaPlante talk about his education outside of the educational system, and how his life resembles what he learns - creative, challenging and most of all - happy.

Why is it that we think we already know what happiness is, what love is, and creativity is... and yet we fail at many of them to the point that we spend billions, with a B!, on self help and self improvement. 

Logan inspires me to get my kid out of traditional school and join him on a happy journey towards a happy and fulfilling life.

You're coming?

---------------
#tedtalk   #hacking   #happiness   #selfhelp   #selfimprovement

comments.text:
So this kind of schools does exist - an example is the one created by a 
friend of this boy's Mum where he is learning how to write (as he said in 
his presentation). It is a good idea, and valuable at many levels. However, 
to put it into practice at a national level, it needs to consider ways by 
which to make it feasible in economic terms, so that it becomes available 
to everyone.
A great presentation and an amazing perspective on education, no doubt! My 
only concern though, is regarding the opportunistic feature of it (as 
explained by the boy). Community life is only called upon when useful to 
the person under this type of education. Even if it is said that work in 
community is an aspect of it (of this kind of education), the hacker 
mindset is worrying to the extent as it disregards the freedom of others. 
To think creatively is definitely FUNDAMENTAL but so it is to think about 
the Other, for the Other’s sake – not ours.
One cannot be happy without the Other and without contemplating his or her 
own interests – something often implies giving in. Happiness has to do with 
a symbiotic notion of community and not with a harsh or insensitive 
procedure that often characterizes the work of hackers who are literally 
only after fulfilling their own plans, disregarding whoever may constitute 
and obstacle to the achievement of their idea. 
Having said this though, this kid is definitely a 5 start speaker and if he 
continues this way, a bright future awaits him!
Thanks for the post.
comments.author: Mafalda Pereira da Cunha

not necessarily. there are lots of online type educational programs parents 
can have their kids do so they dont have to be really intelligent 
themselves. it just gives them control and direct access to what their 
children are learning about. or you can have a family outing at a park that 
involves exploring nature around them, looking up info about plants and 
animals right in front of them on a smart phone rather than reading about 
it and looking at pictures in a text book in a stuffy, boring classroom. 
the parents can even learn right alongside their kids as they help them or 
have a discussion about a topic, whenever, wherever.

i think what he's getting at is, the majority of kids who get bad grades in 
school do so because sitting and being lectured to is just not a very good 
way for kids to learn. what with the technology we have at our fingertips 
today, learning can and should happen ANYWHERE, because getting kids 
involved hands on, learning at their own pace in their own way usually 
reaps far better results than shoving knowledge down their throats.

I was actually home schooled for all my schooling (with the exception of 
college and university) and I was actually in a lower middle class family,

and haven't come out any worse off then anyone who went through public 
education. Again, it's not perfect or for everyone, but neither is public 
education. It's good to have alternatives to both, because, everyone learns 
differently.

comments.text:
I like this. I think his eight subjects are a good start for health and 
happiness, but I wouldn't use them as a complete guide to education. I 
could easily see how to connect these to required subjects for 
documentation's sake though:
1. Exercise (PE)
2. Diet & Nutrition (Health and/or science -- especially 
microbiology/biochemistry if you get way into it.)
3. Time in Nature (biology, wildlife biology, botany, zoology, entomology, 
ornithology, physics, soil chemistry)
4. Contribution & Service (Occupational Education. These are those pesky 
volunteer opportunities and internships that college apps love so much)
5. Relationships (Social Studies, history, interpersonal communications, 
writing, reading, spelling, speech, group relations)
6. Recreation (learning through play can cover every subject under the sun, 
but we'll put it as Fine Arts, Art, Music, Performing)
7. Relaxation & Stress Management (humanities. Ha ha.)
8. Religious & Spiritual (also part of Social Studies, especially cultural 
awareness).

The only thing I find missing is a study of mathematics, but I could easily 
throw that one in with the science of nature as well as the contribution & 
service sections.

This does give me a few ideas for things to change for our next homeschool 
year, but I realize we're already doing many of these.
comments.author: Amy Knepper

comments.text:
+Andrew Ward : A lot of that is actually really dependent on the state 
requirements, and they're vastly different per state. In Nevada, all I had 
to do was submit an "Intent to Homeschool" form to the school district 
every year, and we were told to go have fun. Here in VA, I have to submit 
the ItH as well as one state approved standardized test score per kid. 
Here, we've opted to go with the California Achievement Test, since VA 
approves of it, the fees are minimal ($25 per kid), and we can take it 
online, so the results are available immediately as a PDF (minimizes the 
chances of scoring machines screwing up, things getting lost in the mail, 
etc).

We "get away with" quite a lot, because outside a very small curriculum 
that ensures they get to their "test required milestones", we utilize 
what's around us, the library, and take full advantage of any and all free 
resources we can. When the time comes, the girls can either go for their 
GEDs if they're desperate for a certificate, take a correspondence course 
for a "real diploma", or many colleges simply accept their yearly test 
scores as their transcripts in lieu of a diploma, if they even require a 
diploma at all (many don't, and happily accommodate homeschoolers of all 
stripes).

Now, as far as economics, yeah, we're definitely "lucky" in that we're able 
to keep me home and live on one income so I can facilitate learning for the 
kids. Some families are able to make it work, and I've seen a number of 
other families band together to form co-ops of sorts, wherein families with 
stay at home parents take in neighborhood homeschooled kids while their 
parents are at work, but it's rare because homeschooling and alternative 
education (if we can be so bold as to umbrella all other forms of 
non-public-schooling under one term) aren't considered "normal" yet.
comments.author: Lindsey “Fi” Clements

comments.text:
The main problem I see with that kind of educational system, is that it 
requires a level of out-of-the-box thinking that most of the general 
population is either wholly uncomfortable with or unprepared to do, and it 
requires a community willing to accommodate that brand of unconventional 
schooling. 

Then there's the issue of *documenting* that education. Because there's not 
a lot of potential employers who will accept a diploma from My Laptop At 
Starbucks High School. The unfortunate reality is that society as a whole 
is not set up to accommodate an education that didn't originate in either a 
public school, private school, or homeschool.

I suppose you could get away with this in a homeschool setting (as long as 
the state-mandated equivalency tests are still administered), but 
homeschooling to provide this sort of educational opportunity is simply not 
an option for a lot of families dealing with the realities of the current 
economic climate.
comments.author: Andrew Ward

top_comment.text:
*Hackschooling -- Have you heard of it?*

Sir Ken Robinson tells us that schools kill creativity, and this TEDx talk 
by Tahoe teen Logan LaPlant offers an alternative to traditional school 
that he calls *Hackschooling.* According to the very eloquent LaPlant, 
school should focus on raising children to be happy and healthy adults.

Says LaPlant...
"I’m not tied to one particular curriculum, and I’m not dedicated to one 
particular approach. I hack my education. I take advantages of 
opportunities in my community and through a network of my friends and 
family. I take advantage of opportunities to experience what I’m learning, 
and I’m not afraid to look for shortcuts or hacks to get a better, faster 
result. It’s like a remix or a mashup of learning. … And here’s the cool 
part: because it’s a mindset, not a system, hackschooling can be used by 
anyone, even traditional schools."

I'm not a homeschooler, but I do have reservations about traditional 
schooling, especially when it's tied to so much standardized testing. I'd 
love to hear what you think.

#hackschooling   #hackschool   #creativity   #education   #tedx   #tedtalk 
  #kbn   #20moms  ﻿
top_comment.author: Rachelle Doorley

comments.text:
+jami milton I've long thought about this topic, but it's really coming to 
a head now that my oldest is about to enter Kindergarten. I'm glad to hear 
that despite the testing, you're still seeing a lot of positive benefits

comments.author: Rachelle Doorley

comments.text:
Rachelle, this is really interesting. Thanks for sharing. Now that my 
oldest has been a kinder in a traditional school, I'm starting to get the 
impact testing has on the day-to-day curriculum - even at the kinder level. 
The kids engage in lots of "busy work", instead of playing. And so much 
time is spent bouncing between these academic activities. There's a huge 
emphasis on following instructions. As it were, I think my son is 
benefitting greatly from the structure. Surprisingly, he loves school and 
his teacher. He loves the work. And so far, I'm only seeing his creativity 
expand. So far so good, but I've heard things change a lot by third grade...

top_comment.text:
Exercise is a big part of gym class and is a required class for all kids. 

Diet and Nutrition are handled by the kid's parents while at home and the 
school's lunch gives kids the required nutrition for said meal. 

Time in Nature? This is subjective nonsense, some kids absolutely despise 
nature it's all about the child's personal preference. 

Contribution and service? Do children really care that much about helping? 
Anytime my nephews decide to "help" around the house, they do help for a 
moment, but quickly grow bored and drop the task. This desire to help seems 
to be mistaken curiosity. 

Relationships is a good point. Children should form happy and healthy bonds 
with others, but this does not mean the child shouldn't be subject to 
criticism.  A big problem with today's notion of bullying is that it 
provides a simple but inadequate solution to a very complex problem. 
Sometimes a kid needs to be made fun of. It's how we learn humility and 
grow based on social pressure while it doesn't matter so much. You ever 
wondered why you see so many adults behave like overgrown children? It's 
because they were never criticized by their peers. This special snowflake 
syndrome is causing people to think they're more significant than they 
actually are. Don't get me wrong, I'm not condoning harassment, but a laugh 
or two at little Jimmy's sake isn't a big deal. 

Recreation is also a good point. Kids like to play and should be allowed to 
do so. 

Relaxation and stress are also key points that he never really delves into. 
 A child should experience a balance of both in order to best prepare them 
for adulthood. Childhood isn't there to pander to how kid's want to live, 
it's there to make them capable adults. 

Religion and spirituality are not a key requirement for a happy child, and 
to say so in front of an audience like it's fact really makes TED look bad. 
There are many happy secular kids out there. 

Healthy, happy and creativity, and the "hacker" mindset are important to 
education are they? 

Kids should be healthy, but attempting to keep everyone happy all the time 
will lead to disappointment. Kids need to learn to associate failure with 
sadness or discipline. It's absurd to pretend that keeping these kids happy 
all the time should be up most importance. 

Creativity is a good thing in some people, but to say that we should 
harness such a vague concept that varies from person to person and attempt 
to expand upon it is silly and inefficient. You've also got to have a 
willing kid which ,more often than not, you don't.  

Experimental classes and camps are an absolutely terrible idea to use on a 
large sample. What if these new classes and camps don't work properly? What 
do we do with all the kids we've misinformed? Children aren't test dummies, 
and using this vague new schooling system would create quite a few problems 
in terms of regulation. 

Technology and online resources. Coming from an IT guy who works on 
computers kids have been on, I can tell you firsthand that the moment 
they're put on a computer to work their first instinct is to goof off. 
 Their history is 80% games and 20% educational sites of which they will 
inevitably rush through because a computer is a toy and not an instrument 
of learning for them. You've also seen about how well online classes do in 
terms of teaching. This could work if we are able to shift the computer 
from a form of entertainment to a tool of learning, but I have no clue how 
to go about doing that. 

"'Hackschooling' is a mind set, not a system," he says. This is the 
problem. You can't possibly hope to enforce this feel good mindset on kids 
from the ghetto or broken homes. Kids who have no interest in learning and 
will abuse this newly proposed system. The traditional education system 
works because it is that, a system. It needs some work, but it works well 
enough for the average student. 

He also needs to be prepared to write about a prompt and not just what he 
fancies. Part of the dull writing prompts is preparing the student to think 
critically about something they otherwise would pay no mind to. The stuff 
Ms.Page taught us wasn't exactly my top priority in terms of stuff I want 
to write about, but it did teach me about researching and writing a paper 
on an unfamiliar subject. I'm glad this kid loves writing, but this will, 
once again, be abused by those who dislike it. If kid's aren't made to 
broaden their minds, they never will.  I also dislike how he seems to think 
it's easier to teach yourself than it is to receive instructions from a 
teacher. Could you imagine learning calculus without a teacher? It wouldn't 
work. The concepts are just too difficult to grasp without someone more 
experienced guiding you. Self education is akin to deriving the knowledge 
for yourself. Will it work and stick to your mind better? Yes, but it will 
move along at an abysmal rate if completed at all because most students 
will give up. 

They also seem to be spending more time on field trips than actually 
learning in class. This is neat, but some complex stuff simply cannot be 
demonstrated. The whole idea of a mathematical concept is demonstrating the 
effect on paper. They also seem to have volunteers from tons of 
organizations to educate these kids. We'll run low on volunteers if this is 
applied to every school. 

I could go on, but there are many flaws in this new system of education. It 
is proposed as a solution, but it could do not such thing. It has potential 
in students who show initiative, but cannot easily be applied to every 
student.  ﻿

top_comment.text:
*Gör skolan helt fel?*

Jag vet inte vem det var som länkade till detta någon dag sedan i mitt 
flöde, jag brukar öppna nya flikar av intressanta länkar och gå igenom dom 
senare när jag har mera tid...

Nåja, Logan LaPlante är 13-år gammal och hade en föreläsning på Tedx ang. 
något som han kallar för #hackschooling , det handlar inte och hacking som 
jag trodde i datortermer utan mer hur han har anpassat sin egen 
individuella utbildning i hemmet. Som lärare tycker jag det är otroligt 
intressant att fundera på hur vi skulle kunna göra om det svenska 
skolsystemet, *(det fungerar ju tydligen inte enligt PISA undersökningarna)*. 
Ett koncept som jag tror skulle fungera är Googles 20% teknik, att en dag i 
veckan skulle elever få plugga det som de tycker är mest intressant!

Hackschooling är helt klart något jag måste kolla närmare på med, direkt 
börjar jag tänka att det inte skulle fungera, det finns ju så många andra 
saker som eleverna tycker är roligare! Det är ju redan nu svårt att få 
många av dom att koncentrera sig...

Vad tror ni där ute? skulle hackschooling kunna fungera i den svenska 
skolan?

#hackschooling   #loganlaplante   #Pedagogik  ﻿

Oj, jag har så många tankar runt det här och Pisa! 

I jämförelse med de länder som sprungit förbi oss, undrar jag om det är så 
att Sverige faktiskt ligger efter - eller om vi ligger före. Och då tänker 
jag i ett tänk, även om det är svårt att tro, att skolan börjat anpassa sig 
till det faktum att vi lever i ett kunskapssamhälle där inte skolan längre 
är den självklara eller ens enda leverantören av kunskap . Pisa har jag 
förstått bygger på teoretiska kunskaper och att kunna prestera och visa dem 
på ett gammalt traditionellt sätt. Om vi halkar efter där då våra elever i 
allt större utsträckning börjar arbeta kreativt, upptäckande och modernt - 
tyder det per automatik att vi blivit sämre? Eller att vi kanske anpassat 
både våra kunskaper och hur vi använder och redovisar dem efter ett 
högteknologiskt samhälle som i större grad skriker efter andra kunskaper 
och förmågor än algebra, periodiska system etc? 

Nu flummar jag och tänker högt. Återkommer när jag bestämt vad jag tänker 
:)

comments.text:
+MightySpaj
I see what you're saying when you say that everyone is a nice person 
inside.  Children are smiling and laughing much of the time, and have an 
easy time bonding with each other.  Children and toddlers are so important 
to mankind:  they are more human than any of us.  They haven't been 
brainwashed or conditioned in any way, so they are closest to what the best 
possible human condition would be like.  Are children worrying themselves 
into bad health?  No.  Do they have a burning desire to learn new things?  
Yes.  Do they have more fun than adults?  Yes.

You could argue that they are naive children, but are they naive, or just 
not conditioned by society yet?  They are unaware of dangers as well, but 
that's what parents are for.  It's the brainwashed parents, that are part 
of the problem.
comments.author: MeecrobMan

comments.text:
+Tobias Wulff I'm not assuming that I'm right, their happiness levels are 
actually higher because they are grateful for what they have, whereas 
modern society focuses on materialism, status etc. which is the opposite of 
happiness.

Yes you can 'choose' what you want to become going through the system, but 
both the system and society influence/control us into making bad decisions. 
People don't follow their passions, they do the opposite and follow a path 
that someone else has set out for them. If we are all different, how can we 
put through the same system and expect good results?

Obviously this is just one example, but my cousin got a 97.5 ATAR (which in 
South Australia means 97.5/100) You would assume that she has a good career 
path set out for her, correct? Well that's not the case, because she didn't 
even know what she wanted to do and chose her course at the very last 
minute. And I literally mean the last minute, I was at their beachhouse and 
she was freaking out because she didnt know what to do.

The reason why is because people are taught not to follow their passions, 
we are told not to be different and in system basically strips you down 
until you are fit for only a minimal set of autonomic tasks. If you ever 
want to find your career/purpose, you have to be your true self. Once 
you're your true self, following the right path comes with no effort. The 
reason why people make such bad career decisions is because *no one is 
being themselves*, which both the system and society can be blamed for.
comments.author: MightySpaj

top_comment.text:
Does he accept evolution as true? A massive majority of home schoolers get 
taught intelligent design. Just that thought alone turns me off. It's one 
of the key problems with homeschooling. You can learn anything you want, 
and half the time, it's going to be wrong. Sure, it might work for the 
basics when you're 10, but at 15, when you need to go deeper?﻿
top_comment.author: Mikel Syn

comments.text:
My brother and I were both homeschooled (by choice) in middle school and 
high school.  We had moved to the bible belt and were bullied  for being 
the only atheists in public school and because we had refused to join 
prayer circle every morning/voiced our concerns with prayer in the public 
school system.  This day in age most homeschooled children are set up with 
an accredited homeschool program so they can actually attend college after 
they graduate high school.  To graduate, you CAN'T learn anything you want, 
as you stated. The accredited school sends you course work that you are to 
complete and hand in within a set time frame.  Outside of your studies, you 
can learn whatever you want, and you certainly have more time to do so as 
you are not stuck inside a classroom with busy work all day.  My education 
through my homeschool program was the best education I ever received and it 
definitely didn't fail me. It allowed me time to volunteer and participate 
in other social activities I wouldn't have otherwise had time for.  I also 
graduated college with honors, a year earlier than my peers.
comments.author: Natalie Banas

comments.text:

kind of a myth, or an overblown truth. Good point though.

The big bang is still a theory, which most adults doubt. 2nd home schoolers 
achieve better in higher education and in applications to the Ivy league. 
100 years ago most were still home schooled, general schooling was just for 
the poor. Modern school is basic generalization without meeting the needs 
of todays children or society. Hence graduates and school standards are

that internet is a great tool for knowledge, and my bachelor degree didn't

I'm walking the path by myself, I also want to contribute to the education 
of others, in the future. By cause and effect (of by the law of attraction, 
as you want) I'm finding a lot of people who shares the same vision than I, 
from different points of view, talents, potential and experience. But we do 
share one thing, and the most important: We know that this has to change, 
and we will contribute to the change. But we have to be patient, persevere, 
analize, empathize and be tolerant and understanding as well.

comments.text:
Justin —

The average homeschooling family spends $500 per child per year.  The 
average public school spends about $10,000 per child per year.  Despite the 
spending disparity, homeschoolers on average rank in the 87th percentile 
for national standardized tests (meaning 87% of all students score lower).

The point is that homeschooling parents make a conscious choice to place 
their children's education higher up the family priority scale than the 
majority of people do (about 4% of children in the United States are 
homeschooled).

Your perception of homeschooling being the province of the "spoiled rich 
white person" is far from the reality.  There are families at all economic 
levels homeschooling their children, including families on welfare. 

See http://www.topmastersineducation.com/homeschooled/ for a lot more 
statistics that you might find interesting.
comments.author: gaelwolf008

If you have the same level of motivation, you can make the public education 
system work to your advantage.  Many have.  While you still have to learn 
the mundane, that really doesn't take much effort or time for those of us 
with a higher intellectual capacity.  Beyond that, there are often 
non-standard classes, programs, and clubs one can join to create a tailored 
education plan.  The problem is that these options aren't available in all 
schools for monetary reasons mostly because the bulk of school funding 
comes from property tax, leaving rich communities with the best schools and 
poor communities in the educational gutter.

top_comment.text:
For all those "home" schooling parents out there (you may have already seen 
this, but just in case). The actual idea of "hack" schooling is not 
explicitly defined or communicated in this video, but the idea of making 
education work for you is something that is promoted as worthwhile. Also, 
this video could further spark the discussion between a normative 
curriculum, one where we determine what the child should learn, and 
exploratory curriculum, where the child pursues what they want to learn. ﻿

"Sir Fred Hoyle was an English astronomer noted primarily for his

controversial stance on other cosmological and scientific matters—in

comments.author: Rasaki

comments.text:
+Arpit Waghmare
Oh "faith"! That's a fascinating topic for education... for me. Though it 
extends beyond "schooling" (even homeschooling) because in a sense we are 
witnesses, evangelists and even missionaries to our children... though of 
course in the best of ways (in that way I too agree that we must not force, 
coerce or "buy"/reward their faith). When dealing with faith I have my own 
presuppositions.... and so I govern my actions around those.

1. (in no particular order)... there is no neutral non-faith space. Every 
space is influenced by a worldview/religion/ideological perspective. 
Western *and now eastern* animated/non-animated media for instance is one 
of those powerful (though sometimes seemingly neutral) perspectives that 
influence that attitudes, perspectives and sometimes even 
actions/behaviours of our children (not all is bad, though, i also think, 
especially if parents are involved in the watching/interpreting).
2. Children need help/guidance in what is reality AND how to interpret the 
reality they see. Their "why" questions are research questions... they want 
to know... not just the "truth" but what is the correct perspective... how 
to look at reality. (they may not be aware of it, but they are asking for 
both content AND method to get that content). Sometimes we give too much 
content, sometimes we give good content with wrong methods, and sometimes 
good method with wrong content. Ideally, and I think I agree with you, that 
we want our children to be able to question, make decisions for themselves, 
be assertive (in a positive way, not be swayed), and be humble etc.... and 
much of this comes through the WAY we arrive at the answer and how we 
communicate and not simply in telling a child the answer.
3. Faith, the Christian faith, I believe, is one such perspective... like 
the world's perspective. And it is ok for christian parents to speak from 
within that perspectives... hence to pray, to go to Church, etc will 
naturally influence the child, but to NOT go to church because we want the 
child to be "free" is another perspective as well, that will also 
influencing the child... (even if it seems more politically correct)... 
(for example, one our friends are raising their daughter to make up their 
own mind about faith, but it looks as if they themselves have wanted to 
keep an open mind about their own faith). So I think our faith expression 
in the lives of our children is a valid, necessary, and God-given mandate 
for our children.
4. Another assumption... children are not ready to understand/comprehend 
grapple with all the perspectives/ideologies the world has to offer.  And 
so, to intentionally go out and see alternative theories to God, especially 
if it is forced as a curriculum, rather that emerging out of natural 
conversation and exposure... may not be the best way to treat the child... 
and may even overwhelm them. Certainly some difference is needed, but 
difference, lack of "truth" / even alternatives, are evident more easily 
than we think. Starting from our own contradictions as parents where we do 
not live up to our own high ideals (and then we tell Taarika that we are 
not acting as we would want)... to talking about the neighbouring temple, 
Beatles music (that is not about Jesus, but still nice to listen to), to 
understanding the context of festivals like Diwali/holi to the recognition 
that there are those who believe in Jesus and those who do not. Apart from 
this exposure... which in itself is so much that needs a lot to process and 
unpack... I don't think we need to go too much out of our way to enforce 
the exposure to difference... especially we if remain critically away of 
the differences close within.
5. I assume that the right method is one that takes a lot of time and 
cannot always be communicated through content (ie. we cannot "tell" the 
right method). In terms of the method for faith, therefore, I also believe 
that the true way of understanding takes time. While I do want a child to 
be critical/self critical/parent critical.... I also believe that it takes 
time and maturity on the part of the child. In time the child, I think, 
will go through the next phase of the journey.... we need not enforce 
self-critical processes/methods right now. So while we do a lot of faith 
expressions (sometimes overt and sometimes less overt), still we have also 
tried to express that true understanding (ie. true belief in Jesus.. and 
how I express it to taarika is the ability to not just talk to God but 
listen to Him and be led by Him... comes through time... when she is older 
(and in my view .... which at this age I will not tell her just yet... 
through the process of being critical of parent's faith and deciding for 
herself if this is indeed true). Here again, I would trust the child to 
grow up feeling resentment to the parents and parent's faith. Almost all 
the people I've had a serious conversation with about their childhood to 
maturity journey... have confessed of something like this.... a journey 
that takes place... for some it is a crisis... for others it is less 
dramatic... but the process where the parent's God, the Sunday School God, 
the Bible God, the God of Abraham, becomes my God, will take time... and is 
prone to risk... because the child may, regardless of parenting, choose 
another way, but it is at that moment the freedom to choose by the parent 
will be most critical and hardest.

So... within these assumptions I operate. There are certainly many more... 
but mainly on the issue of "freedom" and "exposure" I mention these.
comments.author: Nigel Ajay Kumar

comments.text:
For Christian homes ­ does Jesus exploring his own education/faith at age 12
ring a bell? :-) I am grappling with the need to give our children autonomy
even in what they believe. Perhaps they need to be given freedom even to
explore their own journey with God. Been reading Peck lately and agree with
much of what he says about what he calls 'spiritual growth.' Of course this
must be done within boundaries ­ and that is the struggle ­ how do we define
those? Maybe a good answer is to model the faith at home, have our family
prayer, conversations about God, learning of Bible verses but give them the
freedom to adopt it for themselves when they are ready (as against
orchestrating the process).At some stage (when?) the kids should be free to
evaluate the faith of their parents in the light of their own experiences
and other world views. For this they need to be exposed. Hence I believe if
they are participating in the faith practices at home, it is all the more
important for their education to help them critically interact with their
faith ­ rather than unduly reinforce it. That might lead to superficial
faith. Hence I would like my kids to understand evolution deeply rather than
protect them from the world view of the evolutionists! I believe this
approach is less dangerous and more rewarding than it sounds.

Would love to hear opposing viewpoints. Will really help us flesh out stuff!
comments.author: Arpit Waghmare

comments.text:
+Arpit Waghmare
normative vs exploratory simply because this video is so strongly 
pro-exploratory. The child defines his education as HIS education, HIS own 
plan, his own interests... with much confidence, even. Hence it brings to 
focus whether such a thing is relevant for us... is it too ideal a picture 
for today's children... in Christian, Indian homes... or is it something 
that we should encourage.

comments.text:
Jane —

As a psychologist, you should know by now that in any large group of 
individuals, there will be outliers to the norm.  Some of those outliers 
will significantly outpace the capabilities of that norm.

As a healthcare professional, you should also be aware of the 
responsibility you have to ". . . first, do no harm."  It might be 
appropriate for you to consider what harm your words may have on the 
impressionable mind of the young adolescent who you publicly appear to be 
so dismissive of.

When you say that Logan's talk was "clearly written by somebody else", you 
should, as a trained psychologist, be prepared to demonstrate that he would 
not be capable of writing an eleven minute talk on how he learns and why he 
has chosen to become educated.

You are far from the first person in this comment stream to have asserted 
that there's no way he could have written this on his own.  In saying that 
you are ". . . sooo surprised that no one mentioned it here by now . . ." 
you have demonstrated that you have yet to take the time to review a 
representative sampling of the available comments.

You have also evidently have yet to perform a simple Internet search using 
"logan laplante" as your search phrase.  Had you done so, you would have 
been able to learn that Logan wrote and delivered his TEDx talk as a change 
from his three previous years tackling of Young Chataqua events as a 
presenter.  Developing and delivering this talk was a schoolwork assignment 
that he challenged himself to.

As to the content being "ok" . . . I observe that Logan's presentation is 
resonating strongly with families, educators, and publications all over the 
world.  You don't see that with something that's just "ok".

So . . . as one of the "guys" you so artfully put down as not being 
observant, may I be the first to respectfully request that you turn your 
skills as a trained (and practicing?) psychologist to actually spending 
some time researching what this young man as accomplished through his TEDx 
talk and reporting back to us at your earliest convenience?

Once you have done so, you may find that an apology to Logan and his family 
is in order.

Could I do this at age 13? No. But I'm rather surprised that no one has 
made critical comments such as (1) skiing takes lots of money, and so does 
the educational lifestyle afforded to this kid; (2) lots of children actors 
are this poised, and there's no reason to think that his dropping out of 
school is the reason he is so seemingly smart in absence of the 
aforementioned money for his skiing trips and wilderness adventures; (3) in 
essence, he's being home-schooled, a system that has produced geniuses 
(look up Erik Demaine) and people who think the world was created 6,000 
years ago; (4) our U.S. education system, for all its troubles, has 
produced millions of creative thinkers, just not at the rate we seem to 
think they need to be produced; and (5) come on, not one person thought he 
was at least a tiny bit spoiled and smart-alecky?﻿
top_comment.author: Christopher Wanjek

comments.text:
+gaelwolf008 OK. I guess time will tell. I've seen bright self-taught kids 
on the streets of Brazil, too. Without resources (i.e. money, access, 
cultural privileges), it's a hard road to success this way. I'm just 
wondering the practical applications of a deliberate choice to have your 
child drop out of school and pursue "hackschooling."  What might be working 
for this child might not have worked for the 300 clever kids who are the 
current semi-finalists in the Intel science contest.
comments.author: Christopher Wanjek

comments.text:
Christopher —

Since you have managed to collect most of the critical comments that many 
others have expressed in this thread, please allow me to address each point 
in your collection, so that we can also have some responses to each point.

As you note, there are not all that many thirteen year olds who could stand 
in front of a large audience of adults and give a well-conceived 
presentation for more than eleven minutes.  The fact that we now have 
nearly four million views of the video here is a testament to the fact that 
Logan has managed to gain world-wide interest as a result of his family's 
and his educational philosophy.

Skiing does take some money, but there are many ways for a family that is 
involved in competitive skiing to significantly reduce most of the costs.  
Logan and his brother are top competitors for their age groups.  The family 
goes above and beyond in terms of cost-savings to support the competition 
tracks the boys are on.

Wilderness adventures are extremely low-cost for families that live in 
locations surrounded by wilderness and public lands.  The area where 
Logan's family lives certainly qualifies in that respect

While it may be a little easier to support a homeschool / hackschool 
lifestyle at a certain financial comfort level or above, it's not necessary 
for a family to be wealthy in order to homeschool.  There are many cases of 
single-parent households with incomes well below governmentally-recognized 
poverty levels who have successfully homeschooled their children.  What is 
necessary for this to happen is for the parent(s) to make a conscious 
decision to place their children's educational needs at the top of the 
family budget priority tree, right behind food and shelter.

While many child actors can appear to be poised, that's certainly not 
necessarily true.  Most of them are working from a script.  Logan was 
working from the product of the educational process leading up to his 
presentation.  He's the one who put it all together.  (He wanted a change 
from his previous participation in the Young Chautauqua program.)  In order 
to make it all work, he had to be a goal-oriented self-starter.  A large 
part of that comes from family values, work ethic, and many other positive 
attributes.

His leaving the traditional educational setting for homeschooling / 
hackschooling is, as you note, not the reason he is so "seemingly smart".  
What it does demonstrate, however, is that he has escaped the restraints of 
the traditional classroom and the pressures (formal or informal) against 
performance at a student's maximum potential.

Homeschooling does not produce geniuses.  It can, however, allow a student 
with a high IQ to become educated in an environment that encourages 
engaging with information at a higher level than is possible in a 
traditional classroom setting where teachers generally have to work within 
imposed standards more often designed to produce good workers than fully 
actualized leaders, thinkers, and innovators.  While our public education 
system has produced creative thinkers, you are correct in stating that this 
doesn't happen at the rate we need for the challenges we face as a society.

Your jab at homeschooling producing "people who think the world was created 
6,000 years ago" is entirely gratuitous and inappropriate in the extreme.  
Just as our society has extreme progressives and extreme conservatives, 
families who participate in homeschooling / hackschooling come from all 
walks of life and all belief systems.  While their numbers are smaller than 
those families who use the public school system, you'll likely find that 
the bell curve is similar for both groups.

I have known homeschooling families who are extreme off-the-grid 
progressives living in yurts, and I've known some who are devout 
evangelical Christians.  I've also known homeschooling families all across 
the socioeconomic and spiritual spectrum.  The one point they all have in 
common is that their children are nearly all well ahead of their age 
cohorts in educational achievement, regardless of the IQ or socioeconomic 
factors they start with.  These are going to be some of our most successful 
adults and societal influencers.

Look at society as a bird.  Every bird has to have a fully formed and 
functional left and right wing.  So, too, for human society.

As to your final point . . . no, I did not find Logan to be "spoiled" or 
smart-alecky".  I saw a confident, witty young man who put himself into a 
position to talk about his passions and his chosen path of education.  We 
could do with more like him.
